case_name: Divisional Forest Officer, Sarahan Forest Division and Chief Conservator of Forests, Himachal Pradesh v. Smt. Besroo and Smt. Rupi

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated December 12, 1963 of the Judicial Commissioner court, Himachal Pradesh, in Civil Writ Petition No. 19 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1963 of the Judicial Commissioners court, Himachal Pradesh, in Civil Writ Petition No. 19 of 1963.

facts.text: Certificate granted by the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh for the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate granted by the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh, is directed against his judgment

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner allowed petition filed by respondents and issued writ of mandamus to appellants to issue permission for felling trees and transit pass for certain khasra numbers.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against his judgment allowing a petition filed by the respondents and issuing a writ of mandamus directing the Divisional Forest Officer. Sarahan Forest Division, and the Chief Conservator of Forests, Himachal Pradesh --hereinafter referred to as the appellants--to issue or get issued the necessary permission for felling the trees and the transit pass. in respect of certain khasra numbers.

facts.text: Land measuring 27 bighas and 16 biswas comprised in khasra Nos. 452/1,453, 453/1, 40, 100 and 440 situated in village Kadiali, Tehsil Theog, District Mahasu belonged to Government and was under tenancy of Moti Ram.

anchor.surface_text: Land measuring 27 bighas and 16 biswas comprised in khasra Nos. 452/1,453, 453/1, 40, 100 and 440 and situated in village Kadiali, Tehsil Theog, District Mahasu, belonged to Government and was under the tenancy of Moti Ram.

facts.text: Moti Ram filed application under s. 11 of the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He filed an application under s. 11 of the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953--hereinafter referred to as the Act--and was granted proprietary rights in the land by the Compensation Officer

facts.text: Compensation Officer granted proprietary rights in the land to Moti Ram by order dated August 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and was granted proprietary rights in the land by the Compensation Officer by order dated August 30, 1957.

facts.text: Provisional compensation assessed at Rs. 62.56 nP.

anchor.surface_text: Provisional compensation was assessed at Rs. 62.56 nP.

facts.text: Compensation Officer held Moti Ram as cultivating tenant entitled to acquire right, title and interest of land-owner on payment of Rs. 62.56.

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer held that as the applicant is a cultivating tenant over the aforesaid land he is entitled to acquire right, title and interest of the said land-owner on payment of Rs. 62.56 as compensation which should be deposited.

facts.text: Certificate of ownership granted to Moti Ram on September 9, 1957 after depositing Rs. 62.56.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1957, a certificate of ownership was granted to Moti Ram on his depositing Rs. 62.56.

facts.text: Moti Ram died and land mutated in favour of his wife Smt. Besroo and daughter Smt. Rupi.

anchor.surface_text: Moti Ram died and the land was mutated in favour of his wife Smt. Besroo and his daughter Smt. Rupi.

facts.text: Respondents applied for permission to sell trees on their land.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents applied for permission to sell the trees on their land,

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer permitted respondents to sell trees from their land by order dated July 18, 1958 on certain conditions.

anchor.surface_text: and the Divisional Forest Officer by order dated July 18, 1958, permitted them to sell the trees from their land on certain conditions.

facts.text: Respondents deposited Rs. 1267.13 nP as government fee on November 15, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On November 15, 1958, the respondents deposited Rs. 1267.13 nP as government fee,

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer failed to give clear orders for felling trees and taking out converted timber.

anchor.surface_text: but the Divisional Forest Officer failed to give clear orders for felling the trees and taking out the converted timber from the said land.

facts.text: Chief Conservator of Forests informed respondents by letter dated July 12, 1961 that matter was being inquired from Conservator of Forests, Simla Circle.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Conservator Officer, by letter dated July 12, 1961, informed the respondents that the matter was being inquired from the Conservator of Forests, Simla Circle.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, number hearing anything further, the respondents flied a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer contended that respondents had no interest in trees as trees were not land as defined in s. 2(5) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before the Judicial Commissioner, on behalf of the Divisional Forest Officer that the respondents had number interest in the trees standing on their land as. the trees were number land as defined in s. 2 5  of the Act,

facts.text: Compensation Officer was not competent to grant proprietary rights in trees to Moti Ram.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Compensation Officer was number competent to grant, and, in fact, did number grant proprietary rights in the trees to the deceased Moti Ram.

facts.text: Respondents were granted permission to sell trees and entered into agreement to sell to third party and deposited Rs. 1267.13 nP.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that the respondents were granted permission to sell the trees standing on their land and they had, in fact, entered into an agreement to sell to a third party, and they had deposited Rs. 1267.13 nP and had thus acted to their detriment.

facts.text: Trees standing on the land transferred to Moti Ram under s.11 are worth about Rs. 76,000.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants contends that the trees standing on the land transferred to Moti Ram under s. 11 of the Act are worth about Rs. 76,000,

facts.text: No contention raised in written statement that trees are forest trees or worth Rs.76,000.

anchor.surface_text: But numbersuch contention seems to have been raised in the written statement filed by the appellants.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Land defined in s. 2(5) of the Act as land not occupied as site of building and occupied for agricultural purposes etc., including orchards.

anchor.surface_text: But we are companycerned with a different question and the question is whether under s. 11 of the Act trees are included within the expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land of the tenancy. It seems to us that this expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land is wide enough to include trees standing on the land.

arguments.claim: under s.8 Transfer of Property Act transfer of land includes trees unless different intention; construe s.11 similarly

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that under s. 8 of the Transfer of Property Act, unless a different intention is expressed or implied, transfer of land would include trees standing on it. It seems to us that we should companystrue s. 11 in the same manner.

arguments.claim: Punjab and Lahore cases distinguishable as concerned alienation restrictions not rights transfer

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion those cases are distinguishable inasmuch as they deal with the question whether trees companyld be sold or assigned under the Punjab Alienation of Land Act without infringing the prohibitions companytained in that Act forbidding sale of land by agriculturists in favour of number-agriculturists.

If the companytention of the learned companynsel were. companyrect, even cultivable land which is expressly mentioned in s. 84 a   i  would number vest in the tenant under s. 11 of the Act.

arguments.claim: accepting narrow view leads to confusion, interminable disputes over trees/fruit rights

anchor.surface_text: Further, it seems to. us that it would lead to utter companyfusion if the companytention of the learned companynsel is accepted. There would be interminable disputes as to the rights of the erstwhile landowners to go on the lands of erstwhile tenants and cut trees or take the fruit.

arguments.claim: under s.15 trees on landowner's land would not vest in State if narrow view, which is absurd

holdings.text: The expression 'right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land' under s. 11 of the Act is wide enough to include trees standing on the land

anchor.surface_text: But we are companynerned with a different question and the question is whether under s. 11 of the Act trees are included within the expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land of the tenancy. It seems to us that this expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land is wide enough to include trees standing on the land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of the wide expression; no different intention expressed

holdings.text: s. 11 of the Act should be construed in the same manner as s. 8 of the Transfer of Property Act, whereby transfer of land includes trees standing on it unless different intention expressed or implied

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that under s. 8 of the Transfer of Property Act, unless a different intention is expressed or implied, transfer of land would include trees standing on it. It seems to us that we should companynstrue s. 11 in the same manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to general property transfer rule in TPA s.8 applies absent contrary intention in the Act

holdings.text: Decisions of Punjab Chief Court and Lahore High Court interpreting similar definition in Punjab Alienation of Land Act are distinguishable

anchor.surface_text: He relies on a number of decisions of the Punjab Chief Court and the Lahore High Court interpreting a similar definition existing in the Punjab Alienation of Land Act XIII of 1900 . In our opinion those cases are distinguishable inasmuch as they deal with the question whether trees could be sold or assigned under the Punjab Alienation of Land Act without infringing the prohibitions contained in that Act forbidding sale of land by agriculturists in favour of non-agriculturists.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited cases concern separate sale/assignment of trees under alienation restrictions, not whether trees pass on transfer of rights in land

holdings.text: Contention based on s.84 (consequences of vesting under s.83 expressly including trees) rejected; does not imply exclusion of trees under s.11

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this contenention. Section 84 a i reads as follows When a notification under section 83 has been published... If the contenention of the learned counsel were correct, even cultivable land which is expressly mentioned in s. 84 a i would not vest in the tenant under s. 11 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would lead to absurdity excluding even expressly mentioned cultivable land from s.11; s.11 simply vests full ownership in tenant

holdings.text: Narrow interpretation excluding trees would lead to utter confusion and interminable disputes over tree/fruit rights

anchor.surface_text: Further, it seems to us that it would lead to utter confusionsion if the contenention of the learned counsel is accepted. There would be interminable disputes as to the rights of the erstwhile landowners to go on the lands of erstwhile tenants and cut trees or take the fruit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive: avoids practical chaos in land reform implementation

holdings.text: Under s.15, narrow view would absurdly exclude trees from vesting in State

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, under s. 15 of the Act we would, following the same reasoning, have to hold that the trees on the land of the landowner did not vest in the State. This could hardly have been the intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction avoids absurdity across related vesting provisions

holdings.text: Judgment of Judicial Commissioner upheld (though for different reasons); appeal dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on above legal determinations on s.11

precedents.citation: Vijay Kumari Thakur v. H. P. Administration 1

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner, following Vijay Kumari Thakur v. H. P. Administration 1 held that the appellants were estopped from contending that the respondents had nointerest in the trees. He further held that the respondents were granted permission to sell the trees standing on their land and they had, in fact, entered into an agreement to sell to a third party, and they had deposited Rs. 1267.13 nP and had thus acted to their detriment.

precedents.case_name: Vijay Kumari Thakur v. H. P. Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: appellants were estopped from contending that the respondents had no interest in the trees

anchor.surface_text: For instance, in Achhru Mal v. Maula Bakhsh 2 , under a deed of sale the vendee was entitled to cut and remove the trees within a period of ten years, and the plaintiff brought a suit asking for a perpetual injunction to issue to the defendants-respondents to restrain them from preventing him from cutting and removing certain trees from the land belonging to the defendants-respondents- The lower courts held that the trees growing on agricultural land were land within the meaning of the expression as defined in s. 23 of the Punjab Alienation of Land Act, and, therefore, their sale to the plaintiff was unlawful having regard to the provisions of that Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: sale of standing trees is not a sale of land under the Punjab Alienation of Land Act
precedents.cited_holding: the sale of trees was not a sale of land

anchor.surface_text: In Nasib Singh v. Amin Chand 1 it was held that the suit for possession of certain mango, shisham and jaman trees was not a suit between a landlord and his tenant under the Punjab Tenancy Act and consequently the Civil Court was competent to try the suit. There can be no doubt that trees are capable of being transferred apart from land, and if a person transfers trees or gives a right to a person to cut trees and remove them it cannot be said that he has transferred land.

precedents.cited_proposition: suit for possession of trees is not under Punjab Tenancy Act; trees capable of being transferred apart from land
precedents.cited_holding: the suit for possession of certain mango, shisham and jaman trees was not a suit between a landlord and his tenant under the Punjab Tenancy Act and consequently the Civil Court was competent to try the suit

anchor.surface_text: But no such contention seems to have been raised in the written statement filed by the appellants.It might have been different if it had been proved that the portion of the area transferred to Moti Ram was a natural forest.see Kaju Mal v. Salig Ram 2 . The learned counsel referring to s. 84 of the Act points out that one of the consequences of vesting of land in the State Government under s. 83 is that trees expressly vest in the State.

precedents.cited_proposition: natural forest trees may be treated differently

anchor.surface_text: But we are companynerned with a different question and the question is whether under s. 11 of the Act trees are included within the expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land of the tenancy. It seems to us that this expression right, title and interest of the land-owner in the land is wide enough to include trees standing on the land.
For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that under s. 8 of the Transfer of Property Act, unless a different intention is expressed or implied, transfer of land would include trees standing on it. It seems to us that we should companynstrue s. 11 in the same manner.
For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: He relies on a number of decisions of the Punjab Chief Court and the Lahore High Court interpreting a similar definition existing in the Punjab Alienation of Land Act XIII of 1900 . In our opinion those cases are distinguishable inasmuch as they deal with the question whether trees could be sold or assigned under the Punjab Alienation of Land Act without infringing the prohibitions contained in that Act forbidding sale of land by agriculturists in favour of non-agriculturists.
For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it seems to us that it would lead to utter confusionsion if the contenention of the learned counsel is accepted. There would be interminable disputes as to the rights of the erstwhile landowners to go on the lands of erstwhile tenants and cut trees or take the fruit.
For the aforesaid reasons we must uphold the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, although for different reasons. In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
